byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Thomas Erdbrink from Tehran; Ozgur Ogret from Istanbul; Salman Masood from Islamabad, Pakistan; Zia ur-Rehman from Karachi, Pakistan; and Sheikha al-Dosary from Washington.

abstract: Stampede in Mecca that resulted in deaths of over 700 pilgrims performing hajj in Saudi Arabia has caused differences between Shiites, Sunnis and other Muslim sects to come to the fore, even though pilgrimage is meant to unite adherents to Islamic faith; stampede has also caused many to criticize Saudi Arabia and question its management of holiest sites for Muslims.
lead_paragraph: The stampede that killed over 700 near Mecca spurred finger-pointing, with many Muslim countries criticizing Saudi Arabia’s management of the rite.

headline.main: Hajj Tragedy Inflames Schisms During a Pilgrimage Designed for Unity
headline.print_headline: Schisms Flare After Tragedy at a Unifying Rite

snippet: The stampede that killed over 700 near Mecca spurred finger-pointing, with many Muslim countries criticizing Saudi Arabia’s management of the rite.
